div1.head: Jim to M. Kiffin Rockwell May 25th, 1915
div1.p: One of our men is leaving for Paris to morrow and I’m sending this note in by him to be mailed from there.

I hope things are coming along fine for you now and that you’ve gotten back your usual cheerfulness. Cheer up, mon vieux, for Italy marches and that will mean a few more dead enemies. Speaking of that reminds me. I went up to the first line trenches the other day, a line that had, with two others, been taken from the Boches, to see the burying of the dead. The fire had been so hot that no one could go out to get the bodies and they were in a bad state. I won’t go into the gruesome, or however you spell it, details of the burying of decaying French and German dead behind the lines, for I haven’t time to do it justice. out front There were a few bodies remaining ^ and we were looking for those. On our way back from the first line, and just as our boyau merged into the second, we smelt two corpses and were told they were about half way out between the second and first line. The young lieutenant with me pulled down some sand bags and wriggled out on his stomach. I followed but forgot to keep low and zing a bullet went by. I stayed down after that. One of the bodies, both of which were German, proved to be an officer. He was a fearful mess. His face was no longer a face but a black ball of putrid flesh out of which and over crawled swarms of magots [sic]. Teeth shown out of a bloated mouth giving a grinning look to the thing. The officer called a couple of brancardiers out to him. They examined the body for identification and then the lieutenant ordered him dragged to a marmite hole near by. They pulled him by his boots and his head
came off. Then he broke in the middle, and they had to start all over again. After three crawling trips he was collected and duly interred. The other corpse was more reasonable and remained intact during the haul.

When the lieutenant and I had returned to the burying ground near the edge of that murdered part of nature known as Le Quart en Reserve we sat down and talked. Pretty soon a marmite came snarling thru [sic] the shattered, desolate woods and the officer rolled over on his stomach his arms protecting his head. Pow [sic], and the eclats went over us. The third was damn close and had I not been following the lieutenant’s method of dodging I’d have gotten mine, for a large, robust and very speedy chunk sang over my dome by a two foot miss and sunk in the edge of an excavation.
Things have been very quiet “around these parts” of late. Zora Lee Fry has gone to visit her uncle out on Route No. 3, and the crops look good.

Paris is sending us a big Hotchkiss car for sitting cases and that will help a lot. By the way some officers around here tell us we’re going to get mentioned in the order of the day. Some class if that comes off. People are beating it out of town and as a result I have a most wonderful billet. The Chief and I have a whole apartment along with a garden to ourselves. I’m living up here all the time now.
